oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Voting District 29-2, Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Reverend L.O.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Voting Rights
Suffrage; African Americans; African American men; African American women; African American children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color film footage showing African American women standing in line, two African American men assisting a small boy walking on a porch, a sign reading 29-2 "Vote Here," African American men standing in line leading to tents with placards, and an African American man in a suit and zig-zag striped tie standing next to an automobile.

The Reverend Lonzie Odie Taylor (circa 1899-1977) became pastor of Olivet Baptist Church, 270 East Calhoun, Memphis, in 1931, serving the church until the 1950s. He was also a prolific photographer, whose black and white images of Memphis's African American community, both posed in a studio setting and in the busy business district of Beale Street and neighboring areas, captured a dynamic period of middle class prosperity and achievement from the 1920s to the 1960s. Taylor also made 16mm films, including this excerpt showing voters at a temporary neighborhood polling place. Blanche Taylor donated her husband's invaluable archive, which consists of thousands of negatives, five hundred still images, approximately 15 hours of color and black-and-white film, sound recordings, and manuscripts, to the Center for Southern Folklore.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Courtesy of Center for Southern Folklore
